title: 114_s2526
content: The Act titled "Made in America Manufacturing Communities Act of 2016" establishes a program to designate and support manufacturing communities. The Act establishes a program to improve US manufacturing competitiveness by designating and supporting manufacturing communities. The Act supports designated manufacturing communities under subsection (c) by providing preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance to consortium members. The Act allows agency heads to give preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance to consortium members who align with the economic development strategy and meet all requirements. The Act allows agency heads to provide financial or technical assistance to consortium members who align with the economic development strategy and meet applicable requirements. Participating agencies include the Department of Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Housing and Urban Development, and Labor. The Act allows agency heads to provide assistance to consortium members aligned with the economic development strategy. Participating agencies include Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Transportation, Appalachian Regional Commission, Delta Regional Authority, Environmental Protection Agency, National Science Foundation, and Small Business Administration. The Small Business Administration identifies applicable programs for the established program under subsection (b) in participating agencies. Multiple members of the same consortium can seek assistance. The Small Business Administration identifies programs for participating agencies. Multiple consortium members can seek assistance for the same program. The head of an agency can determine how preference is given to consortium members for financial or technical assistance. If multiple members qualify for preference, the agency can require the consortium to select who should receive it. The head of each participating agency must submit a report to the Secretary within 90 days, detailing how preference will be given to consortium members for financial or technical assistance. The participating agency must report to the Secretary on how preferential consideration will be given to consortium members for financial or technical assistance. Additionally, the Secretary may provide a Federal point of contact to help consortium members access funds and technical assistance under the manufacturing community program. Financial or technical assistance may be awarded to a member of a manufacturing community consortium under a program established by a participating agency. The assistance must align with the economic development strategy of the consortium. A recipient of financial or technical assistance may use the funds to support investments in infrastructure and access to capital to improve US manufacturing competitiveness. The recipient of financial or technical assistance may use the funds for various purposes such as infrastructure improvements, access to capital, promotion of exports and foreign direct investment, equipment upgrades, workforce training, energy efficiency, business incubators, site preparation, and advanced research. The Secretary of Commerce coordinates with participating agencies to identify programs for infrastructure improvements, access to capital, promotion of exports, equipment upgrades, workforce training, energy efficiency, business incubators, site preparation, advanced research, and supply chain development. Inter-agency coordination is also required among the participating agencies. The Secretary of Commerce coordinates with participating agencies to identify programs for infrastructure improvements, access to capital, promotion of exports, equipment upgrades, workforce training, energy efficiency, business incubators, site preparation, advanced research, and supply chain development. Inter-agency coordination is required to leverage complementary activities and avoid duplication of efforts in the designation of Manufacturing Communities by the Secretary. The Secretary designates eligible consortiums as manufacturing communities through a competitive process. An eligible consortium includes an institution of higher education and a private sector entity. The eligible consortium for manufacturing communities may consist of an institution of higher education, a private sector entity, and a government entity, along with various partners such as economic development groups, financial institutions, and labor organizations. The eligible consortium for manufacturing communities may include a lead applicant such as a district organization, an Indian tribe, or other community and labor groups, financial institutions, or utilities. The eligible consortium for manufacturing communities may include a lead applicant such as an Indian tribe, a State, or a political subdivision engaged in economic or infrastructure development activities. The eligible consortium for manufacturing communities may include a local government, institution of higher education, or a nonprofit organization acting in cooperation with officials of a political subdivision of a State. The eligible consortium for manufacturing communities may include a local government, institution of higher education, or a nonprofit organization acting in cooperation with officials of a political subdivision of a State. A consortium may define the region it represents, subject to approval by the Secretary, to contain critical elements of key technologies or supply chain, prioritized by the consortium. The designation for manufacturing communities is for a 2-year period and can be renewed for another 2 years upon application. The Secretary may renew a designation for manufacturing communities for an additional 2 years upon application from an eligible consortium, with the option for modifications if the consortium has changed its composition. The Secretary may renew a designation for manufacturing communities for an additional 2 years upon application from an eligible consortium that has changed its composition. The evaluation for renewal will assess the consortium's eligibility. To renew a designation of an eligible consortium, the Secretary assesses performance against previous terms and project-specific metrics proposed by the consortium. The consortium's application for designation is evaluated based on project-specific metrics, especially those aimed at tracking community progress. Any changes to the consortium's composition or strategy are also considered. An eligible consortium seeking a designation under specific criteria must submit an application to the Secretary for evaluation. An eligible consortium seeking a designation under specific criteria must submit an application to the Secretary, including details like regional boundaries and manufacturing concentration assessment. The consortium must provide an assessment of its manufacturing concentration and rank nationally based on employment, sales, and other relevant measures. Additionally, an integrated assessment of the local industrial ecosystem in the region must be included in the application. The consortium must provide an evidence-based plan for developing components of the industrial ecosystem in the region, including workforce, supplier network, research, infrastructure, trade, operational improvements, and capital access for manufacturing activities. An evidence-based plan for developing components of the industrial ecosystem in the region by making specific investments to address gaps and manufacturing the region uniquely competitive. The consortium will track outcome-based metrics, benchmarks, and milestones to evaluate their strategy for improving manufacturing in the region. The consortium will evaluate the performance of their strategy to improve manufacturing in the region based on regional cooperation and manufacturing concentration. The consortium's proposal focuses on regional cooperation and manufacturing concentration. Previously recognized manufacturing communities will retain their designation. The Secretary may accept transferred funds from other agencies to carry out this section. Previously recognized manufacturing communities will retain their designation.
